awd_titl_txt: Chemistry and evolutionary conservation of a naturally occurring metalloantibody
awd_abstract_narration:
With this award, the Chemistry of Life Processes program is supporting the research of Professor Tom Huxford of San Diego State University to study fundamental questions in metal-mediated protein-ligand interactions.   It is estimated that one third of all proteins are metalloproteins.  The use of metals by antibodies to recognize and bind to antigens is a recent finding.  In this context, Professor Huxford and his students have provided concrete evidence that the murine antibody LT1002 uses two bridging Ca2+ ions in binding to its antigen.  Furthermore, they discovered that the amino acids involved in metal coordination by LT1002 are encoded in the germ-line sequences of antibody genes within the genomes of diverse mammalian species and are also present in several antibodies that have been previously analyzed.  The experiments to be performed under this award are designed to characterize the metal binding potential of the LT1002 antibody and to test the hypothesis that the use of metals by antibodies to recognize their antigens is evolutionarily conserved within the mammalian immune system.

The Broader Impacts of this proposal center upon the design of experiments that can be carried out by undergraduate and Master's degree candidates in collaboration with local industrial scientists. The overall educational goal of Dr. Huxford's research program is to expose a broad number of diverse students to principles of structural biochemistry at an early stage in their academic careers. The Structural Biochemistry Laboratory, in which the proposed research will be carried out, has established and continues to maintain the SDSU Macromolecular X-ray Crystallography Facility that serves biological and chemical researchers across campus.  Dr. Huxford has organized the SDSU Structural Biology Program, an informal association of SDSU molecular biology students, faculty, and researchers who meet together and host lectures and seminars aimed at improving their understanding of experimental approaches that link biomolecular structure and function.

por.por_cntn:
In 2009, student researchers from the SDSU Structural Biochemistry Laboratory used x-ray crystallography to discover that an antibody raised from a mouse to recognize the small signaling lipid molecule sphingosine-1-phosphate (S1P) employs a pair of bridging metal ions in binding to its target.  This provided the first ever direct evidence of an antibody produced naturally by an immune challenged animal that relies upon partially coordinated metals to bind its antigen--a "metalloantibody."  The discovery led us to ask a series of fundamental questions of a chemical nature:  Are the metals required for antigen binding?  Does the antibody bind metals in the absence of antigen?  If so, then which metals can bind?  How many metals bind at a time and how tightly do they bind?  With respect to the more fundamental role of metals in the adaptive immune system we wondered:  How did this antibody gain its ability to use metals in antibody recognition?  Was it encoded for in the genome of the mouse or did it emerge through the processes of mutation, recombination, and affinity maturation that occur as a B cell matures?  How common is metal binding by antibodies in biology?

With funding from the National Science Foundation Chemistry of Life Processes Program, we have now determined by surface plasmon resonance spectroscopy that the original mouse anti-S1P antibody cannot bind its antigen in absence of metals.  We used dialysis coupled with absorbance spectroscopy to discover that the antibody binds to metals directly without the need for antigen.  The antibody prefers calcium, but can also bind to magnesium and barium.  It fails to interact with strontium, manganese, iron, zinc, europium, or gadolinium.  Measuring the strength of the interaction by isothermal titration calorimetry revealed that the association of the mouse anti-S1P antibody with calcium is driven by an increase in disorder (entropy), that it binds with relatively weak (low millimolar) affinity, and that each antigen binding site of the antibody can hold two calcium ions.  We used x-ray crystallography on anti-S1P antibodies under conditions of 100 mM calcium to directly observe that in the absence of antigen the antibody binds a pair of calcium ions in a practically identical mode to its antigen-bound complex.

We used an online antibody genetic search tool to identify the most likely variable light chain gene that gave rise to the mouse anti-S1P metalloantibody and discovered that all the amino acids involved in coordinating the two calcium metals are present and in their correct positions prior to any changes associated with B cell maturation.  This strongly suggests that metal coordination is "hard wired" into at least one of the starting sequences for mouse antibodies.  We next searched through several genome sequences and found similar antibody light chains with all the correctly positioned metal binding amino acid residues in rat, dog, cow, pig, and human.  This indicates that the metal binding chemistry observed in the anti-S1P antibody is generally conserved across diverse mammalian species.  Finally, we searched databases of antibodies that have been biochemically characterized for their amino acid sequence and found two well characterized antibodies with light chain sequences that match our metalloantibody.  The first is a human antibody named Q425 that was identify in the serum of an individual that exhibited resistance to infection by HIV.  Interestingly, binding of Q425 to its antigen, the CD4 receptor on T cells, has been shown to require calcium.  The second is mouse anti-double-stranded DNA antibody known as 2C10, which was identified in a mouse with symptoms of the human auto-immune disease Lupus Erythematosus.  Currently, our efforts are focused on developing our in house antibody expression capabilities through which we will test whether metal binding is supported by the metalloantibodies as they are encoded in the mouse genome and study the specific antigen binding modes of the Q425 and 2C10 antibodies.

Our chemical, structural, and biological data suggest that the unique metal binding chemistry that we have defined in the mouse anti-S1P antibody is broadly conserved across diverse mammalian species and conveys some selective advantage to the organism.  The precise mechanism of that selection remains to be discovered, but we suspect that it involves interaction with phosphate-containing antigens and promotion of robust responses early during development of the immune system.  The NSF-funded research has enabled training of a diverse group of undergraduate and graduate level students in cutting edge biochemistry techniques.  Several of these students have moved on to joss in the biotechnology or pharmaceutical industry and others have been accepted to advanced degree programs.  NSF funding has also supported biochemistry and structural biology in general at SDSU.  We have expanded our instrumental capabilities to support the growing group of collaborators and new faculty working in these fields.  Finally, we have been able to share our stories of discovery through presentations at schools and through participation in on campus science community outreach programs.
